name: The Dexterity Rogue PvM Solo Early Game
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
The Dexterity Rogue PvM Solo Early Game

There's been a few dexterity rogues posted in the forum recently and I've been playing a few
The early game is possibly the hardest part of such builds. Perhaps.

Anyway I thought I would put up for discussion things I'm doing when playing these builds in PvM solo, and things I'm unsure about.
Delighted to hear any comments.
Maybe you guys have different survival strategies
I did a search for rogue guides and this appears to be a bit of a gap, the best I could find was Hip's 3 pure yardstick rogue 40 builds with strategies, and a pre-epic rogue guide for NWN.

1. Weapon Finesse
-> I aim to get this ASAP. Either Level 1-2 (ie with Fighter 1 at level 2 as a bonus feat) or Level 3 (other builds). 
-> Before I get this feat I use a ranged weapon, my go to early game is the Heavy Crossbow for the extra damage (1d10 19-20/x2)
-> even when I get this, I like to make sure my HP and AC is good enough to melee before I commit to it, otherwise I am still using my ranged weapon. If I can die to a critical hit, or get knocked down and die in a round, I'm not going to want to melee.
-> once I get BAB 6+ I switch from Heavy Crossbow to Shortbow (or Longbow if Elf/Martial, Sling perhaps if Halfling) if I am still using a ranged weapon but usually by then I have switched to Melee
-> small and large shields are quite useful if access is available to them. when AB is higher dual wielding is extremely attractive

2. Stealth / Detection
-> Seeing things before they see you (scouting) is very important hence high spot (or listen) + stealth is very important
-> you can then plan a strategy well before you engage, giving you a tactical advantage
-> I aim to max these asap

3. Traps
-> 1 rank in Set Trap is enough for the early game. Minor electrical/fire traps can be set with Set Trap 0 (modified), and average electrical/fire traps with Set Trap 5 (modified).
-> I like some search to detect traps but not overboard
-> I like to put a decent amount early into disable trap. The big nasty traps are minor/average electrical and minor/average fire which have a base disarm DC of 26 +the skill of the setter, (at least until you have an ultra high reflex save with evasion/improved evasion). Retrieving traps is pretty hard low levels with the +10 modifier but more realistic perhaps mid to late pre-epic
-> Craft trap sometimes I put a few ranks sometimes I don't, it depends on whether there are 1. components 2. equipment which adds to craft trap skill (ie Lesser Ring of Trap Creation +5, Gloves of the Artificer +3 etc etc). If there aren't components its not worth investing much in this at all. Even if there are, sometimes equipment + fox's cunning potion can boost the score enough to make minors and average traps to help you through the hard early game.

4. Generating Sneaks
-> Stealth + Sneak Attack with a ranged weapon early game is my go to
-> Even later on this is good until one dual wields and gets 4+ APR faster (for 2-3 attack flurries with dual wielding)

5. Use Magical Device
-> This I view as my 'cheat' ability
-> Wands of Magic Missile will help one hit opponents you normally cannot hit, and Beamdog has recently patched this so it is cheap to buy
-> Certain summon spells are great early game, Animate Dead for Tyrantfog Zombie has great +1 damage soak, Wands with Summon IV are fabulous
-> Wands of fire are ok, I like Wands of the Heavens for flame strike though
-> Low level scrolls such as Bless Weapon (+2d6 divine vs undead!), Mage Armor, Ghostly Visage can be very helpful

6. Improved Knockdown
-> I want to get this on all melee dex rogues, there are just circumstances solo where one cannot flank or stealthily sneak attack

Early Leveling
-> Rogue / Fighter I like to go Rogue 1 -> Fighter 1-2 (weapon finesse + extra feat), then Rogue 2-3 for 2d6 sneak attack/uncanny dodge/evasion asap. More sneak attack damage = more power in general
-> Similar idea with Rogue / Paladin, Rogue 1 -> Paladin 1-2 (disease/fear immunity/divine grace/lay on hands), then rogue 2-3 as above, more rogue more power
-> Haven't done a Rogue/Ranger yet, I assume Rogue 1->Ranger 1 then Rogue 2-3 then whatever you want to do

Stats
-> High dex, Int 14 makes sense to me
-> Con 12-16 also makes sense if you want to melee, I like HP
-> Str vs Dex balance is tricky for me. I like Str 14 to help with encumbrance and a little non-sneak damage but I can see the appeal of dumping it to 10 or even 8 to max out Dex, just means one will go searching for good bags to reduce encumberance and items to boost Str more urgently. Perhaps Str is kind of a luxury type stat for a Dex Rogue

Anyway this looks like enough text & thoughts for now, anyway keen to keep learning + improving

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Those are the rules I follow, mostly. A few more from my list for review:
1. I specifically take Knockdown/Improved Knockdown AFTER BAB 6.
2. Use a shield early on Dual Weapon Dexers until your AB is high enough to dual and to take dual weapon feats.
3. People focus on early sneak Damage. This is 100% correct for grouping characters and not unreasonable for the early Missile weapon game when soloing. However, I tend to find Weapon Spec more useful as it is not situational damage. Sneak Damage is situational through the whole game, but really comes into its power when you have more CC options.

Finally, a caution/suggestion ... much of this approach and others is heavily dependant on the PW. This is effective on WoG, on Arelith and Blackstone, the approach is very different.


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hey Zanithar
Thanks for the reply

Knockdown after 2+ APR/round is certainly valuable solo
Rogues get this earlier than most if they dual wield, if they have an ultra high dex score (ie 18-20 starting dex) I *think* it is viable to even get knockdown early
Especially if you buff yourself with Cats, Bless/Aid etc
If they are knocked down enemies get their Dex/Dodge/Tumble AC destroyed so it might be effective +3-5 AB if they are on the floor perhaps?
Knockdown with 1 APR is valuable in parties or if you have a summon with UMD/Cleric etc. 
Sometimes I wonder if it is valuable solo with 1 APR? Like if you knock them down, then you get your next attack in the next round with them flatfooted? Often they still get their attack in before I get a chance to knock them down again (meaning they aren't flatfooted again) so I don't think it is. Perhaps it is useful against a caster, but then a self-targeted silence scroll might be more effective.

I certainly appreciate Weapon Spec/EWS for sure I like to rush it after 2d6 sneak (I wouldn't get any more sneak before WS unless there are exp penalties or something to consider), getting it earlier is good too. I think you are right re the sneak+2d6 with the ranged weapon, that is the reason why I like it, I don't really like to melee early with my rogues due to the low hit die, but other environments might be safer to do so. That being said the fighter 4 levels is d10 hit die... so heh :) go figure maybe both work fine with adjusted playstyles

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content: Against competent melee AI a 1 APR Knockdown is useless when solo, they get back up and start attacking before the next round's Knockdown attempt so you don't get a sneak attack. Sometimes the AI will pause when recovering from Knockdown, usually when it attempts to cast a spell or switch weapons, but if it's solely melee attacking then there's no pause. If you have both 1 APR and HiPS then it can work, but if you're qualified for Shadowdancer then you're probably close to 2 APR anyway.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
So solo 1 APR knockdown is probably only useful against casters, and only if you have the AB. Get that 2 APR asap! 
Interesting thoughts!

posts.author: Orion

Hail Luj1, thanks for your message

I think in terms of playability HiPS pre-epic is fabulous
Mick has written previously it is a game changer, and I agree completely
If one is only taking a single SD level (which is common), for maximal level 40 BAB taking it at level 21 is ideal, if you are happy to wait
Just a trade off between level 40 power and early game enjoyment of SD
In the end I believe either is acceptable

I think this is another great question as to best (dex) rogue race
I agree Halfling as a dex rogue is very strong, small size for +1 AB / stealth / detection, and +2 dex and +1 AB with thrown weapons means there is a lot of power there. 
Elf would be my very close second choice with keen senses, detection bonuses, +2 dex, longbow proficiency, can dual wield small weapons (like dual kamas or shortswords) without penalties, better improved knockdown, better knockdown resistance, better strength. I think humans and dwarves are good too they avoid a lot of multiclass penalties more easily than elf, and have some other nice features depending what you want.

Looking forward to what others think.

posts.author: The Flying Rodent
posts.content:
Interesting post. A few things I guess to add:

1. BAB and taking HIPS early.

Taking HIPS early is only really an issue if you’re planning on playing a class split that gains and extra attack with BAB 16 at level 20, such as Rogue/Fighter/SD. Missing out on 1 BAB point for a Rogue by itself doesn’t mean that much, but missing out on a whole attack does.

If one plans on making a build like this, then to get BAB 16, they will have to index more heavily into SD early (eg Rogue 12 Ft 4 SD 4, usually this is more common on Monk/SD’s) or index more heavily into a high BAB class early (Rogue 12 Fighter 7 SD 1).

2. Corner Sneaking.

Corner sneaking is basically making use of nearby terrain to hide behind (usually ‘corners’ in buildings, hence the name). Pre-HIPS, this is invaluable. This is most easily done with Monks as they have access to extra movement speed, but any stealth character can make use of this. On a pre-epic Rogue, this is particularly effective when combined with:

3. Mastery Over the Ranged Sneak Attack.

Ranged Sneak attacks work over a distance of 30ft. In game terms, this is a little more than the diameter of a typical Mummy Fear Aura, or around about the radius of a Dragon Fear Aura.

Learn this distance. It’s really frickin useful.

An easy way to learn it is to engage on stationary targets from range when coming out of stealth, then running away to stealth behind terrain and trying again. Try doing this at different ranges, until sneak attacks stop working (which they won’t, beyond 30ft).

Once you feel comfortable that you know what ‘30ft between your target’ is, use this as a tether. Done properly, and combined with corner sneaking, it is near impossible for melee foes at early levels to reach you. Take a mid-range sneak attack pot shot coming out of stealth at an enemy, run behind some terrain to stealth (or use HIPS if you have the luxury), rinse and repeat.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I you take IKD with a Halfling (or Gnome), your knockdown ability will be the same as a medium-sized race with regular KD.  That is not as nice as a medium-sized race with IKD, but it is still useful.

The extra feat, extra skill points, and favored class flexibility are so nice that most of my builds are Human, but certainly not all of them.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Something I noted with dual wielding when I playtesting this dex rogue build draft to level 7 just in the last few hours, is that if the dex stat is quite high, dual wielding feats are much worth it early on provided you have the defenses and HP to survive in melee long enough. 
At level 3 my elf dex rogue / fighter had an AB of 6 dual wielding mundane shortswords. A halfling would get to add +1 to AB from small stature.



Also as a follow up to the 1 APR knockdown thingo. Obviously a 1 APR knockdown is good in parties or if you have summons/familiar/animal to also hit the opponent
But as Yunim noted often the opponent gets an attack in before you can knock them down again, it is less useful without these features in PvM

Interestingly if you get an excellent initiative roll, I have found that sometimes one can consistently knockdown an opponent without them being able to get an attack in when they stand up.
So you can keep them on the floor without receiving much damage. With a poor initiative roll they seemed to get attacks in more frequently before I can try to knock them down again.
Probably most relevant for dexers as they seem to have excellent initiative rolls (haven't looked up the exact mechanics in the Wiki yet), and take a while to kill opponents which are sneak immune
Thought this would be a nice observation to share. Repeated 1 APR knockdown solo might be useful if you roll high with initiative. Roll low with initiative - don't bother.

posts.author: Luj1
posts.content:
My problem is that a Halfling Rogue has only two choices for dual wield - daggers and kukris. Kukri's improved threat range (which is the whole point of the weapon) doesn't really help against SA immunes who are immune to crits anyway.

Furthermore, if you are going with the 10-20-12 spread in Str/Dex/Con (which I believe is the way to go with a DEX-based Halfling Rogue) you likely won't have enough HP to linger in melee range (before level 27 and Epic Dodge anyway).

I guess what I'm saying is that I'd rather drop Kukris and IC and grab a ranged weapon and focus on AB/flat damage.

I think the sling is really a sneaky favorite here, you can use a shield with it and it gets another +1 AB from the Halfling racial.

posts.author: Luj1
posts.content: Dual wielding kukris can potentially require up to 5 feats, a ranged Rogue needs just 2 and gets only 1 APR less (the one with the highest penalty).

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I'm hearing what you are saying Luj1
Elf/Human allows for dual shortswords, handaxe, maces and kamas plus dagger/kukri, all pretty cool weapons

Halfling rogue archers/arbalests/slingers are very strong early on, 
6 AB at level 1 with 20 dex (+5) and small stature (+1) and 0 BAB is superb. 
Slings will get +1 AB, and if you have Point Blank Shot, another +1 AB/DMG when sneak attacking them (8 AB at level 1).

Edit: Oh and rogue archers are monsters in PvM parties. Very easy to setup the rogue archers to unload tons of sneak damage pain, especially if you have a fighter tank with improved expertise to tank for the archer.
Just a little harder solo as enemies will walk up to you, and you will have to switch to melee or trigger attacks of opportunity

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I think you all are not taking into account the new changes to Rogues, Barbs, and Assassins from 1.74 (I think it is that version).

That is, you need to have 4 levels or higher combined in Rog, Barb, and Assassin to get flanking bonuses (re: sneaks).
As of Enhanced Edition patch 1.74, Uncanny Dodge II provides immunity to flanking sneak attacks under certain class level checks between the attacker and defender. See the Uncanny Dodge article for more information.
As of Enhanced Edition patch 1.74, uncanny dodge II grants immunity to sneak attacks from a flanking attacker unless the attacker has at least four more combined class levels of rogue, assassin, and barbarian than the defender. (Shadowdancer and blackguard levels are not counted.) For example, a level 10 rogue would have this immunity when attacked by a level 13 rogue, but not when attacked by a level 14 rogue. This immunity does not apply when the defender is flat-footed. This change is undocumented in the feat description.
Which, depending on the environment, can really shut down SA.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content: There are ways to deal with Uncanny Dodge, the main ones being Knockdown and stealth. Darkness, Death Attack paralysis, invisibility, Stunning Fist, and most disabling spells will also work. It's only really a problem if your Rogue relies on flanking alone to generate Sneak Attacks.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Yes, of course.

I was just commenting on the ranged Rogue that is using his ranged weapons to "flank sneak" in a party.  Or sliding up besides the beefy tank, hoping to slip in a SA.

That the rules have changed now, one has to take that into account.  It is not as easy as it used to be.

Sometimes, opponents are immune to KD.  Casting Darkness could adversely affect your party members (and get them sneaked).  I know you know all this, you are a very experienced NWNer.

But since 1.74, it is not so cut and dried anymore.  I was really just referring to that.
